div1.p: Carter is back at work on Henry Rose Carter's manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever on a half-time basis.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wilbur A. Sawyer, January 10, 1928
div1.opener:
Book
Sick leave (return from)
DIVISION
/////////
-----------
/// //////
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
January 10, 1928.
Dear Doctor Sawyer:
div1.p:
I have the honor to report my return to Washington, and to work on the
MSS of Father's book. I arrived yesterday, Monday, January 9th., but was too
tired from the trip for this day to be counted as one of work.

My stay in Virginia has helped me considerably, although not so much as I had
hoped, owing to the bitterly cold weather of the first part of January. I think,
however, that I am now quite able to work on the book on the half time basis sug-
gested by Dr. Russell in his letter of October 18, 1927 and earnestly hope to so
improve, while thus working, that I can do more later.

In conclusion, may I express my deep appreciation of your kind expressions of
sympathy in regard to my illness? My disappointment at the delay of the work, which
was progressing so well!--has been far worse than any physical suffering, although
that has been considerable.
div1.closer:
With very best wishes, I remain
Most truly yours, Laura G. Carter Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer,
Associate Director,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
International Health Division,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
